statement.tex: %text Find the point on the line $\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$ at a distance $\sqrt{5}$ units from the point $(1,2,3)$. %

options.tex: %text The co-ordinates of a point on line $\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$ are $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$ where $k\in \mathbb{R}$ %
%text The co-ordinates of a point on line $\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$ are $(3k+2, 2k+1, 2k-3)$ where $k\in \mathbb{R}$ %

reason.tex: \begin{align} &\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}=k\,\text{(say)} \\ &\dfrac{x+2}{3}=k\implies x=3k-2 \\ &\dfrac{y+1}{2}=k\implies y=2k-1 \\ &\dfrac{z-3}{2}=k\implies z=2k+3 \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, any point on the given line has coordinates $(3k-2,2k-1,2k+3)$ where $k\in \mathbb{R}$. %

options.tex: %text Since distance between $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$ and $(1,2,3)$ equal $\sqrt{5}$, therefore, % \begin{align} &\sqrt{(3k-3)^2+(2k-3)^2+(2k)^2}=\sqrt{5} \\ &\implies k=1,\,\dfrac{13}{17} \end{align}\\
